ja:head.ce:title:
Development of a NASA roadmap for planetary protection to prepare for the first human missions to Mars
✰

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: As part of planning for future space exploration, COSPAR (The Committee on Space Research) together with participating space agencies, organized and held interdisciplinary meetings to consider next steps in addressing knowledge gaps for planetary protection for future human missions to Mars. Beginning with the results of these meetings and earlier work by NASA, ESA, and COSPAR (e.g., Criswell et al., 2005; Hogan et al., 2006; Rummel et al., 2008) as a base the authors of this paper carried out a follow-on NASA planning activity to identify the necessary steps to be accomplished to close knowledge gaps. We identified significant overlap between the planetary protection needs and other sets of Mars preparation roadmaps (1) microbial monitoring requirements for crew health and medical systems, (2) studies of the microbiome of the built environment, (3) environmental control and life support systems (ECLSS), (4) waste management, and (5) planetary surface operations. In many cases, efforts to mature exploration class systems for Mars that are occurring in other domains can be leveraged with minor changes to address planetary protection gaps as well. In other cases, work planned for testing on the International Space Station (ISS) as an analog for crew Mars transit, or on the lunar surface as an analog for Mars surface operations can be used to close planetary protection technology and knowledge gaps. An overall strategic framework that combines these domains has the advantage of being more comprehensive, efficient, and timely for closing gaps.

This approach has led to the development of a NASA roadmap for addressing planetary protection integrated with other related roadmaps. NASA's development and execution of the planetary protection is now viewed in an integrated way with related technology development and testing. Key features of the integrated capabilities roadmap include:
•
A focus on microbial monitoring needs for crewed systems overall, and the additional work needed to develop and demonstrate baseline vs. abnormal changes in microbial communities over time.
•
Integrated consideration of planetary protection and crew health requirements relevant to crew quarantine and science sample transportation.
•
Specific and targeted studies of microbial growth and biofilms in microgravity and lunar surface ECLSS systems.
•
Development of sterilization, cleaning, and waste handling technologies that meet habitation needs as well as planetary protection needs.

ce:section.ce:para: When developing human Mars mission concepts, NASA acknowledges COSPAR policy ( COSPAR, 2021) as the guideline for protecting Mars from Earth Microbes and protecting Earth from possible Martian microbes. Artemis missions to the Moon will take place before human missions to Mars, but this paper focuses solely on planetary protection for Mars because the COSPAR policy for the Moon is relatively simple based on research that indicates there is no extant life on the Moon ( NASA, 1971). COSPAR policy for the Moon requires documentation of organics delivered to the surface, and specifically for the polar regions, a list of volatiles onboard. Since we anticipate Mars will still be being investigated for evidence of past or present life after the Mars Sample Return mission ( Tait et al., 2022), the envisaged requirements for human missions with regard to forward and backward contamination are much greater, but not impossible to meet ( Fig. 1 ).

The current COSPAR policy ( COSPAR, 2021) for crewed missions to Mars, is based on the text originally added to the policy in 2008, and is qualitative, lacking clear parameters that would help engineers design COSPAR compliant systems for human missions to the Red Planet. To develop quantitative requirements for a human mission to Mars, COSPAR, together with participating space agencies, has sponsored a series of interdisciplinary meetings to consider next steps in addressing knowledge gaps in the planetary protection discipline, ahead of future human missions to Mars and beyond. The objective is to incrementally move from the current qualitative COSPAR Planetary Protection “Principles and Guidelines” toward the development of quantitative Planetary Protection requirements for future human missions to deep space destinations like Mars. The workshops and meetings in this series have involved participants from COSPAR, the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the European Space Agency (ESA), the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), other international space agencies, the scientific and technical community, and commercial and private stakeholders ( Race et al., 2019).

As a follow-on to previous work e.g., Criswell et al., 2005; Hogan et al., 2006; Rummel et al., 2008 and the 2015 NASA workshop, and 2016, 2018 and 2019 COSPAR workshops (and resulting Race et al., 2015, Kminek et al., 2016, Race et al., 2018 and Race et al., 2019 reports) in planetary protection for human missions to Mars, COSPAR supported three virtual meetings — two in 2020 one in 2022 ( Spry et al., 2020). The earlier meetings first identified and then prioritized important knowledge gaps in science and technology areas related to planetary protection for crewed missions, including developing a timeline to assist in ensuring timely closure of the knowledge gaps. Subsequent meetings had considered implementation of strategies to close these knowledge gaps in the areas of “Microbial and human health monitoring”, the “Natural transport of contamination on Mars” and “Technology and operations for contamination control”, to determine potential strategies in managing the contamination in- and outflow of crewed systems on the surface of Mars. Following these workshops, NASA conducted an internal study on methods to prevent backward contamination from Mars and developed assumptions and guidelines concerning management of crew health and possible need for quarantine upon their return to Earth.

NASA used the results from the COSPAR meetings to develop a roadmap to define proper engineering requirements and assess technical solutions for future human-rated flight systems. As stated earlier, Artemis missions to the Moon will occur before human missions to Mars. Even though the COSPAR policy for the Moon is much simpler than for Mars, NASA's architecture philosophy and investment strategy is, to the extent possible, to develop lunar systems with the intent to demonstrate and validate their capabilities for Mars. The roadmap is a tool for identifying early opportunities to close planetary protection knowledge gaps and helps guide NASA's investments on Earth, in low-Earth orbit, at the Moon, and at Mars.

High level knowledge gaps were organized by their priority and where they could be studied, for example if they could be studied on the ground, aboard the International Space Station (ISS), Gateway, the lunar surface, in Mars transit or the Martian surface. Within NASA, a timeline was developed using the knowledge gaps, and including g technology gaps and policy gaps as well. These became part of the agency's capability gaps which are integrated across the human exploration activity of the Moon to Mars program. The capability gaps cover all aspects that we need to know in order to safely get a crewed mission to the Mars surface and back. The Planetary Protection capability gaps were then organized to form the roadmap and ordered as a timeline from left to right. When these steps were taken, overlaps with other roadmaps were identified, such as with Environmental Control and Life Support Systems (ECLSS), Crew Health & Microbial Monitoring and Biological & Physical Sciences. This assists with optimizing activities and funding to support closing the capability gaps in the most efficient way.

Groups of planetary protection Capability Gaps related to crewed exploration were organized into four discipline areas. Fig. 2 shows the first three roadmap categories: Management and Coordination, Microbial Monitoring, and Assessment of Microbial Management on Mars. Fig. 3 shows the final Mitigation techniques category. The different colors relate to where the research to close the gaps can be done, i.e., on the ground, aboard ISS, aboard Gateway ( NASA, 2022a), on the lunar surface or in transit to Mars.

When these steps were taken, overlaps with other NASA technology/capability roadmaps were identified, for example with Environmental Control and Life Support Systems (ECLSS), Crew Health, Microbial Monitoring and Biological & Physical Sciences. This coordination activity assists with optimizing activities and funding to support closing the capability gaps in the most efficient way.

The Microbial Monitoring Integration Team was formed by NASA once it was realized that many different parts of NASA were studying aspects of microbial occurrence and survival. The purpose was to coordinate efforts across the agency, inform team members about what work was already being funded and to eliminate unnecessary duplication.

Microbial Monitoring is a key capability where planetary protection overlaps with crew health applications. Microbial Monitoring can refer to identifying and characterizing changes of microbes within the human and within the environment. Monitoring microbes is needed within the crewed environment is for:
·
Mitigating a contamination threat to Mars (forward planetary protection)
·
Maintaining a healthy and functional environment for the crew to live in
·
Mitigating a contamination threat to Earth (backward planetary protection)

Similarly, microbial monitoring for human health is needed to ensure that it is possible to tell if a sick crew member is just sick, or if they are potentially infected by a putative Martian microbiology, prior to their returning to Earth ( Race et al., 2019). The recommendation from the 2019 meeting was that the ISS was the best platform currently for developing technology for monitoring microbes and to use the best technology available, i.e., nanopore sequencing with the MinION .

Other groups within NASA are also studying microbes and products from their roadmaps feed into the Planetary Protection Roadmap. For example, the Human Research Program studies microbes to protect crew health. They want to know if the microbes change over time and possibly become more virulent. Is there an increase in microbial colonization of the crew habitats? In addition, these scientists want to know if the human immune system changes in space over time. Does the immune response weaken?

There is a clear need to monitor initial bioburden loads, gather systematic data on the status and evolution of microbial communities on both the crew and the crew vehicles, and to understand levels of biological and organic contamination release from crew vehicle systems. This data is not only critical for establishing quantitative planetary protection standards for human missions to Mars, but will also be needed for the design of hardware and operations in compliance with evolving planetary protection requirements ( Race et al., 2019).

The scientists and engineers who are developing the Environmental Control Life Support Systems (ECLSS)-Crew Health and Performance (CHP) systems for Mars, including microbial mitigation and monitoring technologies, have planetary protection-related topics addressed in their multiyear technology development roadmap.

The ECLSS-CHP roadmap intersects with the Planetary Protection Roadmap in the area of microbial mitigation, where experts agree that there should be common microbial mitigation approaches rather than separate approaches for ECLSS-CHP and planetary protection. Microbial mitigation includes the use of filters and biocides inside water and urine processing hardware, HEPA filtering of the cabin air to remove dust, dander, and microbial cells as well as the use of disinfectant wipes for general cleaning of high crew contact spacecraft cabin surfaces. Disinfectant selection is limited by the need to avoid compounds (e.g., halogens, alcohols, ammoniacals) that can damage ECLSS hardware or be difficult to remove from the cabin atmosphere.

Use Cases that address overlapping discipline roadmaps have been developed by the agency. Examples of how the roadmap can address multiple capability needs are described in the following three Use Case examples and are identified in Figs. 2 and 3.

The three Use Case topics identified in the roadmaps are:
1
A capability to monitor microbial contamination. We know that microorganisms are ubiquitous in crewed systems with a changing population over time, both in terms of the abundance and occurrence of different microbial species (e.g., Stahl-Rommel et al., 2021). Microbial monitoring technology has been developed over time for crew health and spacecraft environmental monitoring purposes. This work needs to be further expanded to address planetary protection concerns as part of a Use Case, with generated data being used to develop the capability to detect changes in the spacecraft microbiome resulting from exposure to the Martian environment and/or Martian microorganisms, to inform planetary protection decision-making during human expeditions on the surface of Mars.
2
An ability to be able to understand and track microbial growth and contamination is needed. The occurrence and fate of terrestrial microbiology in the spacecraft environment and exposed to Mars needs to be understood down to the species level, in order that contamination threat can be managed.
3
It is then necessary to be able to mitigate microbial contamination as it is identified or anticipated. Thus, capabilities to process (either by disinfection or sterilization processes) elements of hardware and/or to be able to isolate contaminated material from cleaner environments, either by isolation or containment.
Each of these three capabilities have clear opportunities to be tested and verified by precursor missions in the cis-lunar environment, and the Use Cases are developed in the examples to follow:

ce:section.ce:section-title: Use case 1 – microbial monitoring for crew health
ce:section.ce:para: What: Nanopore sequencing has become commonplace onboard the ISS, where continuous operations have occurred since 2016. In situ analysis was made possible by the emergence of portable molecular biology tools, such as miniPCR bio's miniPCR thermal cycler and Oxford Nanopore Technologies’ MinION nucleic acid sequencer. Both platforms were tested onboard the ISS in 2016, marking the first PCR (polymerase chain reaction) and sequencing to take place beyond the bounds of Earth ( Castro-Wallace et al., 2017; Boguraev et al., 2017). Following these initial demonstrations, a method was developed around these technologies to aid in microbial identifications aboard the ISS. In 2017, a crewmember collected cells from a culture slide used for nominal microbial monitoring, extracted and amplified DNA, generated sequencing libraries, and sequenced the resulting DNA with the MinION ( Burton et al., 2020) . From three colonies, two identifications were obtained. Following return of the culture slide to Earth and analysis following standard laboratory operating procedures, the two identifications obtained aboard the ISS were validated for the three colonies; two colonies were the same organism. This was the first-time that microbes had been collected, cultured, and identified off-Earth. To move beyond the need to culture potentially harmful microbes, a culture-independent, swab-to-sequencer process was developed and tested for the first-time aboard ISS in 2018. During this testing, two crewmembers performed four independent swab-to-sequencer experiments. The data revealed a high similarity with the human microbiome as well as previous culture-based ISS data ( Stahl-Rommel et al., 2021). Not surprisingly, much higher diversity was noted with the swab-to-sequencer method in comparison to the historical culture-based data, as a significant number of difficult-to-culture microorganisms were present ( Stahl-Rommel et al., 2021). Continued onboard validation of this swab-to-sequencer method for surface analysis is ongoing as a part of the ISS Crew Health Care Systems (CHeCS) standard medical operations testing with the goal of moving beyond culture-based analysis for exploration. Additionally, similar MinION-focused, culture-independent water and air analysis methods are undergoing laboratory testing with spaceflight demonstrations planned for the near future. This technology is amenable to a wide range of different sample matrices, expands insight beyond the limitations of traditional culture, and provides a means of in situ molecular characterization that is critical for the expansion of spaceflight missions. Importantly, significant evaluation of both ground- and ISS-generated molecular data has established that it is favorable for use in the current risk assessment framework.

Who: While the focus of the previous work has been directed toward the medical operations community within NASA's Space Operations Mission Directorate (SOMD) including the international partners, it is extendable to all stakeholders with the goal of microbial analysis. These groups include, but are not limited to: Offices of Safety and Mission Assurance, Planetary Protection, Science Mission Directorate, Human Research Program the Mars Architecture team, and space industry.

Where: Currently, this work is being routinely performed onboard the ISS, but the process has been baselined for Gateway, known as the Microbial Surface Monitor (MSM). Moreover, the method and consumables (including shelf life) are suitable for the lunar surface. Based on the methods developed and tested, a high-fidelity concept of operations for in situ microbial profiling exists for these exploration destinations (see “How”).

When: Due to the decades of data and understanding of the Environmental Control and Life Support Systems (ECLSS), microbial monitoring now occurs quarterly onboard the ISS Yamaguchi, 20,14 Stahl-Rommel et al., 2021. For new exploration modules and vehicles, a pre-flight baseline of the air and surface microbiome should be established. For short-duration Gateway missions, sampling should occur at least once per mission. With the addition of new/changing architecture of systems (air and water revitalization), sampling should be performed as frequently as crew time allows, with monthly monitoring being ideal. With the routine use of a completed Gateway or lunar base, sampling could be reduced over time as insight is gained (similar to ISS). However, it is critical to monitor to understand the impact of additions of new biological payloads such as plants or animals.

How: The following is a concept of operations for swab-based analysis. Air and water methods are in work with planned ISS demonstrations in 2023. Briefly, a swab is used to collect a sample from an internal (IVA) or external (EVA) surface. All subsequent steps will take place within a glovebox. Cells from the swab are lysed to free DNA using a combination of enzymes and heat. A paramagnetic bead-based purification can then be used to purify the extracted DNA from the cellular debris ( Stahl-Rommel et al., 2021). The purified DNA will then be subjected to amplification within miniPCR as required by the scientific goals. Following amplification or other barcoding strategy, all samples will be pooled into one reaction and purified using the same bead-based approach, as previously employed. Sequencing libraries will be generated from the purified product by the addition of reagents followed by a brief incubation at ambient temperature. After placing a flow cell into the MinION, the prepared sequencing libraries will be injected into the flow cell, and sequencing will be initiated through the graphical user interface on the MinION screen. Following completion of the run, the data will be transferred from the MinION for in-depth analysis to inform decision making aimed at risk assessment, maintaining cleanliness levels, and other needed planetary protection actions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Use case 2 -terrestrial organism microbial monitoring and survivability
ce:section.ce:para: Why: The microorganisms of Earth's biosphere are ubiquitous, including in engineered vehicles, and humans. It is virtually impossible to maintain a microbiology-free environment in any closed or open systems. If an engineered vehicle comes into direct or indirect contact with humans and other non-sterile surfaces and environments, microbiological transfer can take place. Thus, it is a given fact that where humans and their engineering products go in the solar systems, the associated microorganisms will travel to those destinations, too. As a result, a risk to contamination of exploration destinations exists that could compromise studies to discover, identify, and study indigenous life and their organic chemical signatures on other planets and potentially may seed life at those destinations. Conversely, if viable microbiological organisms are discovered on other planets, the risks exist that these organisms could colonize vehicles and astronauts resulting in the unintentional return to and contamination of the Earth's ecosystem. Therefore, studies are necessary to understand microbial ecosystems and their dynamics concerning mobility, transfer, and survivability in order to accurately define the level of risk, risk factors, and risk mitigation actions concerning human exploration on other planets and return to Earth.

What: The current microbiological characterization and monitoring studies of the built environment conducted on ISS do not faithfully replicate the environment of deep space, the Moon (as an exploration analog for Mars), and Mars. The ISS has relatively little material and equipment transfer from the interior to the exterior compared to Mars estimates where there will be a high EVA frequency ( NASA, 2022b). Furthermore, data concerning mechanisms and modes of microbial migration, transfer, and survival within a vehicle are very limited, including for data available for these same factors for microorganisms on the external surfaces of a space vehicle. Therefore, studies are necessary that investigate microbial ecosystems of exploration vehicles and the astronauts in the actual environment where these missions will occur. The data from microbiological studies conducted in deep space and the lunar environment are critical for understanding the future risk to Mars exploration. The data is important for identifying and filling knowledge gaps concerning microbial mobility, transfer, and survival as it relates to risks to forward contamination of Mars and backward contamination to Earth. Ultimately, the data from these studies will result in developing models of microbial ecosystems and dynamics that may be used for Mars and beyond exploration and defining effective engineering solutions to mitigate risks for microbial contamination.

Who: The microbiological ecosystem is associated with and impacts multiple areas of exploration systems, sciences, and missions. As such the following are anticipated to be stakeholders: Office of Safety and Mission Assurance (OMSA), Office of Planetary Protection, Science Mission Directorate (SMD)-Planetary Sciences Division/Planetary Protection Research Program, Exploration System Development Mission Directorate (ESDMD), Space Operations Mission Directorate (SOMD), space industry, international partners, academia, and SMD-Biological and Physical Sciences (BPS) Division.

Where: The studies on the microbial ecosystem must be conducted in the actual exploration environment, including the transit environment. The elements of these studies include the transit capsules and vehicles (crewed and uncrewed), Gateway, Human Landing Systems, temporary and permanent surface habitats, rovers, surface traverse suits, astronaut body surfaces, and, as accessible, unmanned surface landers and rovers. These studies are conducted on all elements for both lunar and Mars transit and surface exploration.

When: The studies are initiated with the collection of surface samples prior to the launch of any of the mission elements for baseline data collection. Samples are collected during all phases of a mission, including elements that return to Earth. The studies start with the first human occupancy of the Gateway and HLS landing on the Moon. If a direct to Moon plan is implemented, the studies will start with the first lunar landing mission to the moon. If possible, earlier sample collections may be requested for Artemis missions that are lunar orbit only. Overtime, regular monitoring is implemented for all lunar and Mars missions in order to study the microbial ecosystems and its dynamics over time and how it may evolve.

How: Samples are regularly collected from designated surfaces (internal and external; transit, orbital, and surface), crew body, ECLSS, water systems, and air circulation systems at defined timepoints during a mission. In addition, sample are collected pre-flight for baseline data collection and post-flight. It will be important to develop standardized methods for sample collections, sample processing, and sample analyses to get data that can be compared over time and between different missions. The capabilities that will be needed to conduct the microbial investigations include crew time; upmass and volume (sample collection kits and supplies); return mass and volume for collected specimens; in-situ analytical instruments; automated microbial detection and identification devices; air sampling devices; water sampling devices; Glove Box; Incubators; and Microscope.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Use case 3 – microbial mitigation with in-mission production of disinfection agents
ce:section.ce:para: Why: The existing number of disinfection agents compatible for use in a closed space habitat is limited by compatibly with life support equipment, human toxicity, and shelf life. Currently each system and payload independently manifests cleaning and disinfectant wipes and they are not necessarily interchangeable. While wet wipe consumables are readily launched from earth to ISS, deep space missions will require each system planning for its own consumables nominal plus contingencies which can increase overall vehicle departure mass or increased mission and or science completion risks. Currently, no disinfectants are generated in-mission. Wipes are launched wet and individually packaged, with the liquid disinfectant fraction represents ∼80% of the overall wipe mass. If the liquid disinfectant could be generated on orbit and applied to a wipe, then only dry wipes would need to be launched. This would provide a mass savings. It also allows disinfectant to be used for other applications for more extensive cleaning, of interest to PP, of surfaces, tools, or spacesuit components than can be achieved today. For long duration surface missions, laundry of clothing begins to trade favorably over disposable clothing. Once laundry is developed, the wipe substrate could also be laundered if the disinfectant solution is able to be generated. This would reduce the need for launching contingency wipe supplies if wipe reuse is possible.

ISS life support technologies currently have difficulty in removing alcohol-based solvents. Ammonia and halogenated disinfectant solvents can irritate crew or animal senses and contaminate material science in addition to being a challenge for trace contaminant removal systems. Active chemical species can utilize sorbent capacities decreasing their ability to sorbe their targeted chemical species or displace chemical species previously adsorbed. Halogens can also damage catalysts and degrade their performance. Disinfectants that decompose to hydrogen and oxygen (e.g., H 2O 2, O 3, OH −) are generally compatible with closed loop life support systems and do not pose a risk to sorbent or catalysts.

What: An integrated in-mission production of disinfection agents is needed. Disinfection agents should be based on hydrogen and oxygen and should be used for a wide range of mission needs, including: spacecraft interior surface cleaning; life support water system dormancy recovery (tubing/component microbial shock treatment); clothing/fabrics; utilization experiment cleaning; disinfecting EVA items prior to EVA, and; planned/unplanned surface cleaning of material brought into the habitat. A conceptual implementation would be to generate a range of concentrations and volumes of disinfectant solutions. The solution could be applied to dry wipes thereby saving ∼80% of current wet wipe launch mass. Sharing a common dry wipe could reduce contingency wipe mass. It may be possible to reapply disinfectant solution to a wipe (particularly in partial gravity) to allow increased ability to clean larger surface areas. A liquid disinfectant could be aerosolized to provide gaseous treatment of gloveboxes or other spacecraft volumes. Notionally, hydrogen peroxide can be generated from life support portable water used on a wipe or made into an aerosol. The hydrogen peroxide will reduce to oxygen and water with will then be recycled via removal of water vapor from the cabin air via the condensing heat exchanger.
Who: Requires coordinated activity of NASA's SMD, SOMD and ESDMD.

Where: The technology infusion opportunities are primarily on Mars transit and surface missions, but there are potential significant mass benefits for lunar surface and Gateway missions. Prior to these infusions, a microgravity technology demonstration on ISS is required to test with real ISS potable water with trace contaminants, to validate gas bubble management, and long-term generation capability to determine the long-term operation of electrodes and any chemical additives

When: To meet these infusion points, it requires standardization of Use Cases (volumes, concentrations, frequency of use, duration from use identified need to dispense, and liquid/gas state) from the ‘who.’ Demonstration of microbial efficacy and dispensing to required form should be validated with ‘who’ stakeholders throughout the development processes. NASA has microgravity-compatible hydrogen peroxide generation prototype underway under the small business innovation research program (SBIR). Ideally this technology should be further matured leading to an ISS technology demonstration starting in 2026 to inform critical design reviews for lunar surface habitats and Mars transit elements in the 2027–2029 timeframe. The ISS technology demonstration should continue through FY29 to represent at least 3 years of microgravity operation. This should be augmented with ground testing to understand consumable/spares life.

The planetary protection example Use Cases presented lead to needed closure of the knowledge and technology gaps. There were three examples discussed but more need to be addressed. Additional examples to be developed include waste disposal/management on the Mars surface, en-route to Mars and in Mars orbit, spacesuit leakage rates of viable microbes, and others. Knowledge gap closure is essential for development of planetary protection policy and developing requirements for crewed missions to Mars. This will enable timely flow down of Agency level Planetary Protection requirements and adoption into spacecraft design and architecture requirements. Thoughtful and collaborative investments are essential to close these knowledge gaps.

It is important to remember that this a roadmap on how to close the knowledge gaps and not the only roadmap. It will need to be updated as we fill in some of the roadmaps or develop new technologies.
•
Planetary Protection Use Cases presented lead to closure of knowledge gaps.
•
Knowledge gaps closure is essential for development of Planetary Protection policy and requirements for crewed missions, at the Agency level.
•
Timely flow down of Agency level Planetary Protection requirements and adoption into spacecraft design/architecture requirements for the first crewed Mars mission can then occur.
•
NASA recognizes that new investments are essential to close these knowledge gaps.
The work for this paper was funded by NASA Exploration Systems Mission Development.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
